lessons.name: Wellness Quest Kickoff
lessons.description: Start exploring healthy steps for your body and mind.
lessons.lessonText: Today we’ll learn about water, rest, calm breaths, playful moves, and listening to hunger. Each tiny step helps your body feel safe and strong. You can try one at a time and see how it feels.

questions.question: What does water do for your body?
questions.rational: Water keeps your body hydrated and working well.

questions.question: Why is sleep important?
options: It helps your body rest and grow
questions.rational: Sleep helps your body rest and grow strong.

questions.question: What can calm your mind when worried?
questions.rational: Counting belly breaths helps calm your body and mind.

questions.question: Which is movement as play?
questions.rational: Dancing to music is a playful way to move.

questions.question: What is a sign you are hungry?
questions.rational: Stomach growling is a body signal for hunger.

lessons.keyTakeaways: • Wellness is about small daily steps. • Water, rest, play, calm, and food help you feel good.

high_score.message: You’re starting strong—great job noticing healthy choices!

medium_score.message: Nice effort—keep practicing these tiny steps every day.

low_score.message: Good start—try one small step like a sip of water or a calm breath today.

lessons.name: Energy Boosters
lessons.description: Learn how small habits give your body more energy.
lessons.lessonText: Energy comes from sleep, food, water, movement, and calm moments. You can mix them in your day to feel brighter and stronger. Even one small change helps your energy rise.

questions.question: When you feel thirsty, what helps?
questions.rational: Drinking water helps when you’re thirsty.

questions.question: How many hours of sleep do kids usually need?
questions.rational: Kids need about 9–12 hours of sleep to feel rested.

questions.question: What helps you calm before a test?
questions.rational: Slow breaths help calm nerves before a test.

questions.question: What playful move can wake you up?
questions.rational: Jumping jacks are a fun way to wake your body up.

questions.question: Listening to hunger means:
options: Eating when your body feels hungry
questions.rational: Intuitive eating means noticing when you’re hungry and eating then.

lessons.keyTakeaways: • Energy comes from water, food, rest, and play. • Small choices can help you feel awake and strong.

high_score.message: You understand how to fuel your energy—awesome!

medium_score.message: Good job! Try one energy helper today like an early bedtime.

low_score.message: You’re learning—start with one water sip or an early sleep tonight.

lessons.name: Daily Reset
lessons.description: Explore how to recharge your body and mind each day.
lessons.lessonText: Every day your body needs a reset. Rest, food, movement, water, and calm breaths all work like buttons to recharge you. Try using one reset button when you feel low energy or stress.

questions.question: Which drink resets your body best?
questions.rational: Water is the best reset drink for your body.

questions.question: A short nap or good night sleep helps you:
questions.rational: Rest helps you feel refreshed.

questions.question: What helps calm before bed?
questions.rational: Reading quietly helps calm your body for sleep.

questions.question: Which is movement as play?
questions.rational: Tag with friends is movement as play.

questions.question: What’s a gentle sign you are full?
questions.rational: Feeling comfortable in your stomach is a sign you are full.

lessons.keyTakeaways: • Rest and water reset your body. • Calm, play, and listening to hunger help recharge your day.

high_score.message: Great reset skills—you know how to refresh your body and mind!

medium_score.message: Nice! Try one reset step tonight like a calm breath before bed.

low_score.message: You’re learning—start with a sip of water or one calm stretch.

lessons.name: Body Signals

lessons.lessonText: Your body talks through signals like thirst, sleepiness, hunger, and stress. When you listen, you can take tiny steps to feel better. Paying attention makes it easier to care for yourself.

questions.question: A dry mouth means you might need:
questions.rational: A dry mouth is a signal for thirst.

questions.question: Yawning a lot means you need:

questions.question: A tight chest might mean you need:

questions.question: Smiling while moving shows:
options: Smiling while moving means it feels fun
questions.rational: Smiling while moving means it feels fun.

questions.question: Stomach rumbling is a signal of:
questions.rational: A rumbling stomach is a sign of hunger.

lessons.keyTakeaways: • Your body sends signals for thirst, sleep, calm, play, and hunger. • Listening helps you choose tiny steps to care for yourself.

high_score.message: You’re a signal spotter—great job listening to your body!

medium_score.message: Nice effort! Keep practicing noticing one signal at a time.

low_score.message: You’re learning—today try noticing one body signal like thirst.

name: Wellness Checkpoints
description: Learn to pause and check how your body feels.
lessonText: Wellness checkpoints are little pauses in your day. You ask: Am I thirsty? Sleepy? Hungry? Do I need calm or play? These checks help you make better choices.

questions.question: If you haven’t moved in hours, what’s a good checkpoint step?

questions.question: If your tummy is full, what should you do?

questions.rational: Stop eating when you feel full.

keyTakeaways: • Wellness checkpoints help you notice your needs. • Pausing lets you choose better steps for your body.

medium_score.message: Nice effort—try one checkpoint today like checking thirst.

low_score.message: You’re learning—start with one checkpoint like noticing sleepiness.
